awd_abstract_narration:
This project will develop and test the effectiveness of a semester-long conceptually-based instruction for promoting understanding of mathematical equivalence and associated gains in algebraic thinking. Participants in the research will be elementary- and middle- school students. Although many brief, single-session laboratory studies have suggested effective ways to promote equal sign knowledge in the short term, these studies have generally failed to produce practical guidelines for use by regular classroom teachers. This project will apply findings from laboratory studies over a longer time period with the goal of packaging a practical approach to developing students' knowledge of the equal sign for classroom teachers. The hypothesis is that improved equal sign knowledge will lead to improved access to algebra, an important pathway into higher mathematics and science that provides access to Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics (STEM) fields that help power modern society.
 
This project will explore the effectiveness of spaced, conceptually-based instruction for promoting understanding of mathematical equivalence and associated gains in algebraic thinking. Multiple experimental studies have shown that brief, conceptually-based instructional interventions can lead to improvements in children's equal sign knowledge. The proposed research will test whether spacing such interventions over time can lead to more substantial and long-term gains in equal sign knowledge, and whether such knowledge, in turn, fosters algebraic reasoning. One component of the research will aim to optimize the conceptually based intervention. The other component will be a study that investigates the effects of the intervention over time, using a crossover design. The research will employ a measure of equal sign knowledge that is more sensitive than most commonly used measures, allowing for detection of relatively fine-grained gains in response to the instructional intervention. In total, the work will contribute to the field's understanding of how to improve equal sign knowledge and understanding of the causal impact of equal sign instruction on student competence in algebra.

This project is co-funded by the Discovery Research preK-12 program (DRK-12) that seeks to significantly enhance the learning and teaching of science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) by preK-12 students and teachers, through research and development of innovative resources, models, and tools.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Equal sign knowledge is a "big idea" in mathematics that serves as a bedrock of early algebraic thinking. Because algebra is a gateway into higher mathematics and higher education more generally, it is critical that students build a robust, high-quality understanding of the equal sign. However, decades of research have shown that elementary and middle school students consistently struggle to understand the equal sign. Compounding this problem, there are few practical educational resources that provide guidance for instructing children about the equal sign. This research builds upon prior laboratory-based research for improving equal sign knowledge in the hopes of providing practical guidance for classroom instruction. Due to COVID-19 restrictions, we could not conduct research in classrooms as planned, so we investigated children's learning about the equal sign via lessons provided online. We chose to focus on third- and sixth-grade students because these grades mark important points in the development of equal sign knowledge and early algebraic thinking.

We studied the following questions:

  • Could a brief online intervention successfully improve students' equal sign knowledge?
  • How is equal sign knowledge related to algebra knowledge
  • Does it matter whether children understand the equal sign as something meaning that two things are the same vs. understanding it as meaning that one part of a mathematical expression can be substituted or "swapped" for another? Specifically, we wanted to know
    • Whether a substitutive understanding was more developmentally advanced than a sameness understanding.
    • Whether having a substitutive understanding would be associated with better understanding of algebra.

Our work has yielded findings that can inform broader understanding about the nature of equal sign knowledge and how to promote it. Our work has resulted in one peer-reviewed article (Donovan et al., 2022), another manuscript currently in preparation, and multiple conference presentations. Some of our key findings include:

1. When we provided students with brief lessons, their equal sign knowledge improved, regardless of whether lessons were conceptually focused or procedurally focused. These improvements in equal sign knowledge were maintained over time for many students.

2. Students who came into the study with more equal sign knowledge at pretest also had more advanced algebra knowledge at pretest.

3. Students who understood substitutive definitions of the equal sign also understood sameness definitions, but  the reverse was not true. This finding supports the idea that the substitutive definition is more developmentally advanced.

4. We replicated earlier findings that understanding the equal sign as meaning "the total" (also known as having an operational definition) is problematic and is associated both with lower overall equal sign knowledge and lower algebra knowledge.

5. With a brief online intervention, we were able to encourage many students to abandon operational definitions and to adopt sameness and substitutive definitions.

6. When students were presented with problems that made it easier to apply properties of equality without using full calculations, they were able to use more conceptually advanced solution methods. For example, when students saw problems like 67 + 84 = __ + 83, they could reason that the answer must be 66, because 84 is one more than 83, so the blank needs to be one less than 67. By contrast, if they saw items like 60 + __ = 48 + 24, they were less likely to use this method, presumably because of the difficulty in noticing that 48 is 12 less than 60. This may imply that beginning with simpler problems may be best for helping students develop appreciation for conceptually based solution methods.

In sum, our work presents some advances regarding instruction on the equal sign and its relationship to overall understanding of equivalence and algebra. First, it demonstrates that brief online instruction can successfully promote knowledge of the equal sign. This finding is practically important, given widespread changes in educational practice that began with COVID-19, some of which persist. Second, it confirms that both sameness and substitutive conceptions of the equal sign are associated with more advanced mathematical knowledge than operational conceptions. Third, it suggests that substitutive conceptions are more developmentally advanced than sameness conceptions. Finally, it suggests that simplifying aspects of the problems we present to students early on may help them appreciate more advanced conceptual approaches to solving problems. All told, this research provides insights that can enhance practical techniques for improving students' understanding of the equal sign—one of the "big ideas" in early mathematics that supports algebraic thinking. The fruits of this research have the potential to contribute to more equitable and widespread access to algebra and the power that it wields.
